content:
There lives a man atop the Knoll,
Whose greasy fingers seek control;
As days go past, the man yearns for more,
Leaving his home to wander and spread his spores.
In villages he finds the ones in need,
And offering kind help, he plants the seed.
Then they find in their homes a creeping hold
A plant, a vine, a spore becoming mold.

The man returns to his forested abode,
Seeking some comfort, he finds his sickly toad.
The toad cries out, “Now let me go, I plea;
No longer do I want this grassbed home for me!”
The man grows angry and rumples at its nose;
Thus, the toad falls silent, working on its prose.

The Knoll seeks more its grasses growing hungry;
The man feeds it each day with gathered twigs dumbly.
It rumbles loud as colder nights draw near;
So he lies down with it and calls it dear.
The toad then creaks a ribbit filled with fear,
“Please, I implore you now; O lend your ear.
The Knoll is feeding on your lonely mind;
Go to the village, step outside.
In your absence I shall cleanse your home;
The Knoll will shrink, becoming a clean biome.”

The man then laughed at toad’s simple plea;
He knew the Knoll was the worst of any flea.
Yet left the home in hopes the toad was right
That such a creature small could mount a fight.
The days passed on; the toad stayed locked within,
Its throat clogged thick by workings of the Djinn.
Yet it prevailed though nearing its last breath
The Knoll now clean and void of the lethe.

As toad drifted to sleep, the man returned,
Holding a pot with brand new fronds newly un-fern’d.
Though frog had tried, the man contained the stain
A piece of Knoll embedded deep in his brain.
Thus fern took hold and gave the Knoll a path back;
The toad cried out, its lungs burst with spore-filled sacs.

Squire and Knight rode miles together. The Knight, worn thin, still carried steady flame. The squire watched him, light as a feather. “Where do we ride today?”, the squire asked. “My final place. The ground that bears my name.” The squire shrieked in fear, his master now departing. “Who will I learn from whence you are gone? Still full of wisdom left for imparting. Let me die first, for the world will not miss me.” “It will, for it is your time to be called-on” “Then, it is not your teachings but your amity I require. Watch me live as you taught, So I don't suffer grave calamity.” A crow landed on the middle road. “I want nothing more. For this I am wrought.” “Who will find me when I am lost and scared? Or pick me up and guide my way back home? There is more I need, I am lost, Impaired!” The Knight looked stoically straight ahead. “Fear not, for your heart bears my final tome.”
pdfs/Report on AIRP.pdf

Pale pearl paint bled-through with ranges
of mountains and tributaries 
and beyond it, that Canadian
or Appalachian, Nordic, and Siberian.
A heavy axe leaned by a heavy door
meets the soft callus of a sleepy morning-hand
wood burns then, in a stove of stone,
as the aurora shy, starts to sing
and the snow warm starts to fall.

You sit there
or stand
Worrying about worrying
Anxious
about what you’re so sure
will come to be

And maybe
I foresee
the same

We walk here
or run
Careful about caring
Waiting
for these things to leave
for friendship

And maybe
I want
the same

But I know
this cannot stay;
that when I wake
you’re on me.

But you know
this cannot stay;
that when you wake
I’m in you.

And we lay
But feet apart
Reaching and hoping
for the other to give

Maybe it’s too real.
for you –  
And it’s probably too real.
for me –

And then, we lay
together, then apart
pulling and pushing
testing the tie

Maybe it’s too real –
No, that’s what it is;
we’ve pulled enough
and it hasn’t snapped

And we both know
this cannot stay
that when we wake
you’re on me

And I’m in you.

We walk around, here
night after night
day after day
Let’s quit the hoping
and stop the waiting

Let’s wake
like we’ve been wanting
and if we burn

We burn.

And later, they wake
         	From their Series of Dreams
 As breaths taken miles away
         	Feel like kisses on their skin.

        	They cannot see each other
         	Even though they look.
                     	They cannot hear each other
                     	Even though they listen.

And always, outside
         	Puddles sit on the sidewalk
 As yellow surrounds green
         	While the sun hides away.

        	They cannot hold each other
         	Yet, they are not cold.
                     	They cannot grasp each other
                     	Yet they know they’re there.

On and on, they go
         	For the water dances with the wind
 The green grows at the center
         	And the sun can still be found.

                                	They need not hold each other
                                 	Soon, they will be warm,
                                             	And as they long, as they reach
                                             	They know, it’s all worthwhile.

                                                                Forever they’ll live
                                                         	And ever they’ll wait.

                                                                    	And as they lay to rest,
                                                                    	They are longing to live,
                                                                                	
                                                                                	Their Series of Dreams

Way in the woods
 Surrounded by swamps
 Is a bungalow
 With a roof made of dirt
 Walls made of sand
 And a floor of mud
 It has no door
 no windows
 and inside, the same:
 no keys anywhere
 for nowhere, in there
 are there any locks.

In the bungalow
 lives a lonely man
 And everyday
 And every night
 Mothers, from the nearest town
 Fathers and sons, on the road
 Faceless passerby
 And friendly bygones
 Come by
 Some for minutes
 Some for hours
 On their own volition.

With this man
 They open their hearts
 Spill their minds
 And empty their souls.
 And to them
 He gives ears
 He gives eyes
 He gives space
 And, he gives time
 And, he stays,
 never diverging
 until they are done.

And, when they do leave
 And there’s a moment’s rest
 The man lays in the mud
 and he cries.

Even with the oncoming sun
 and the spring it brings
 along with the snow, melting
 turned to soft slush
 making nice puddles for jumping
 and filling the rivers
 for swimming.

Even then:
 with the new enlightenment
 and its sound wisdoms
 along with the new rhythm
 blowing sax and singing soul
 slinging sweet symphonies
 and beating the bell.

How,
 amongst the wiring
 and amid the welding 
 which craft frames
 and draw schematics
 does this all seem
 like semantics?

How, then
 submerged in this salt
 floating along the flotsam
 which, rotting
 smells like a memory
 Seldom lived
 and often remembered?

Maybe, then
 this ardent zeal
 is blasphemous bloat
 tacked on and taped
 to entice the big snake
 that it’s better to sleep
 than to slither.

Or, maybe,
 There isn’t a sheen
 But a sheet of sheens
 and those already passed
 in the past, should stay
 and some select others
 are saved solely for God.


Can you hear me?
 Wherever you are?
 I tell you –
 and it’s all gone

Do you agree?
 how seamless
 and simply strange
 dreams are?

Does your reality
 destabilize and estrange
 blending into dreams
 and blending forth from them?

Is boredom so terrible?
 Relative to hunger?
 Relative to loneliness?
 You’d rather have nothing?

And then
 as the fuselage explodes
 do you imagine
 being stranded at sea?

Floating along
 with shark passerby
 and gulls overhead
 all alone


To then be collected
 and be returned
 so people celebrate
 your own name?

You parents’ embrace
 A friend’s kiss
 and a lover’s touch
 the ocean far away

Do you, then
 wish it were closer
 imagine, then
 you were sailing once again?


Later, can you imagine
 on your death bed
 flowers on the table
 your family gone

The room all white
 Reeking with nothing
 and visiting hours
 not scheduled until later

Can you think?
 what is later.
 when is it?
 and why, then, do you even care?

Can you hear me?
 Because you will
 Dying and alone, you’ll wish
 You were sailing at sea

You will, then
 wish things were closer
 and imagine, then
 you were sailing once again.

Across the stars
 never has there been
 and never will there be
 something quite like this

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Miss the sunset
 and miss the between.

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 To that, at home
 and its gentle hold

So gentle
 and so warm.

Remember this
 and hunt for it
 try to hold on
 - never will it pass again

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Miss the sunset
 and miss the between.

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 From there, the home
 and all you’ve ever known

So gentle
 and so warm.

From this and the next
 Forevermore, it’s gone
 Search for the spirit
 Sated, this will never be

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Miss the sunset
 And miss the between

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 To that, the heart
 So carefully cared for

So gentle
 and so warm.

Across the stars
 never has there been
 and never will there be
 anything quite like this.

One moment, it’s day
 The next, it’s night
 Missing the sunset
 We’ve missed the between.

In its reality
 It’s become unreal
 To that, the mind
 and all we now know.

So gentle
 and so warm.

So gentle
 that we wish we were
 So warm
 all that’s gone wrong.

So gentle, and so warm,
 that we wish we were
 So gentle, and so warm,
 All we know we’re not.

How long will I rot
 until I leap from this bog
 - until I realize
 I can indeed smell
 the stinking smog
 and I can indeed read
 the bloody writing
 sprayed on every building
 etched into every brick
 and shining in the oil
 flooding every parking lot
 and built from the bodies
 filling every city ditch;
 cut into our faces
 and scarred into our thighs
 burned into our bottles
 and scabbed into our scalps
 poisoning our minds
 and infesting our gods
 bastardizing our sons
 and damming our daughters
 and, everywhere else
 written on every wallowing wall.
 How long, will I rot?
 until I realize
 I can, with my own eyes
 unfettered, indeed
 and unfiltered
 unbiased
 and with unaimed prejudice
see all this for what it is.

How long will I rot
 until, from what I know
 I finally act
 How long, will we rot?
 until we finally decide -
 from all we feel from the forests
 and from what we’ve derived
 for so long
 from the deserts;
 from all the skies have said -
 not what’s been contrived
 but what they’ve screamed
 for centuries;
 from all the blood we’ve spilt
 and from the wars we’ve waged
 for no other reason
 than that’s all we know;
 from all the science has shown -
 not that which we’ve decided
 but that, to it
 we’ve assigned truth;
 and from our faiths
 all and one; one and all
 and from our passions
 all and one; one and all
 do we finally decide
 we must make something else.

If it must be
 then let it be a war
 if it must
 then why wait for the war?

A war
 with the forest’s wishes
 and the sky’s blessings.
 A war
 where the blood shed
 is not red
 but black;
 where the science
 ceases to be
 A war
 where our faiths
 and where our passions
 bring down not buildings
 but blow up how little
 we’ve managed to imagine
 A war, not final
 but to begin anew.

How long, must we rot
 until we realize
 we must do it ourselves?

We were never where we were supposed to be
 We never knew
 and never cared
 now, I know
 and now, I care

 I wish
 we could go together.

They’re those left behind;
 those expected yet neglected.
 Forced to douse their lamps
 and made to sail us through the seas.

Unto them, were instilled storms:
 beaten out of them, were their bones
 sucked from them, were their souls
 Lulled away, was their love.

We’re underdecks
 we’re off hidden in the dark.
 Against their arms, are the oars
 as they bear the brunt of the winds.

The acidic rain’s sulfuric;
 it’s raking and tearing at their flesh.
 The rotting bread’s wet;
 scattered, the rats hoard the crumbs.

The frozen winds howl;
 it’s eroding at their skulls.
 The black waves bring sickness;
 a few more have drowned away.

Muffled their voices are
 shouting and calling through the planks –
 through their welded muzzles
 and sewn-shut hoods.

Stumbling over every swell
 Is our odyssey doomed.
 Down here, a few drops leak through
 So few, are those piercing the net.

The storms are perfect
 in our science and design:
 they’re beyond atomic;
 their fallout will be everlasting.

They’ll eventually leave
 having succumbed to the storm:
 they’ll be sentenced to the sea
 face-up, or face-down.

We’re underdecks
 we’re off hidden in the dark.
 And we’ve our own lamps
 and we’ll have grown enough food.

 There are so few galleons, now
 and the little leaks are so many
 is nobody left
 to sail our sinking ship?

To our odyssey doomed
 Has our storm
 Really killed
 All who could’ve landed her?

 Where have they gone?
 Those that would have?
 With solely a spoon
 Those that would have?

My addictive friend
 shivers in the summer.
 It whimpers as you sing
 and itches as ears ring.

I’m a turnstile
 slapping right to left
 and lurching back again
 between this vice
 and that well-worn tune
 with its weathered notes
 and whose melody
 was never that good
 anyway.

My addiction
 shivers in the summer.
 Please, one more time sing
 so I may feel that ring.

I’m a workhorse
 trudging from here to there
 and lurching back again
 between this task
 and my newest obligation
 with its tired rhythms
 and whose steps
 remind me awfully
 of my old music.

I, alone
 shiver in the summer.
 I’ll bury it under anything
 so my ears don’t ring.

Please, one more time, sing
 Sing for me
 So I may hear that ring

Friend
 who’s tired and sad
 Trying so hard to seem hard
 There’s respite in us
 and you may not show it
 but I know you know
 and this, you know too.

My friend,
 you spend the night taking.
 You’re so scared of sharing
 from you, so much was stolen
 and when you reached out last
 open-handed
 you were beaten down again.

Friend
 you hide yourself
 like you’ve always done
 and these people you take from
 and those taking from you
 likely, they’ll never know
 you’ve even a mask.

My friend,
 you’re too stubborn to stop
 and too stuck-in to ask
 May you find someone
 who, against your shell
 will bring a shovel
 and you may share with them
 that which you always were.

My beautiful baby
 Hands on the pavement
 and feet in the grass
 Eyes tied shut
 And hair let down
 its bright waves gold
 falling over your shoulders
 and settling
 just past your breast
 When you turn away
 And, head high
 Eyes open, then
 And your fingers feeling
 Keep going
 and don’t ever stop.
 When, after the storm,
 the grass tickles your toes
 And, when,
 after the drought
 it scratches your skin
 let it burn
 and let it melt
 Let it all come apart
 until your ashes
 swept up
 by that sudden wind
 blow away
 until all that’s left
 is scattered all over
 by that little lightly hue
 and still;
 let it burn
 and let it melt
 But please
 My beautiful baby
 don’t ever
 not even for a thought
 begin back down that way
 that took everything
 and abandon this:
 these gifts
 of something.

Across the tablecloth
 I foresee what will be said;
 I know what’s been shared
 and i even
 relate
 to you

And I say nothing
 No words your way
 just expressions
 diluted and reserved
 muted
 muzzled

I used to wait for a question
 To which, I’d answer
 But now, that’s gone
 I hold back
 deeming it simple
 too easy

At this table
 I don’t make it ours
 I leave it yours
 only waiting
 to leave

I lay
 and wish I spoke
 I could and I can
 but, I’m back there
 and i long to leave again.

I tell you this
 in doing so
 I adhere to my heart.
 All those things I’ve offered
 the suggestions and lessons
 that you’ve adopted
 and have, I think,
 healed with –
 I validate.
 I live truthfully
 through my dogma
 I’ve so zealously
 enticed you to.

I tell you this
 and I’m not a hypocrite.
 I do this thing
 and
 it’ll be me
 following my heart
 that droning machine
 clicking on every hour
 rimming through the night
 I’d be unplugging it
 soothing that itch
 you so easily
 just like every time
 before
 enflamed.

I tell you this
 and everything’s back on
 we’re back on the track
 running our miles;
 walking with our moon
 and fishing our creeks.
 Once more, that fox,
 will sit before us
 and cock its head
 as those fireflies
 mate in the night.

I
 don’t
 tell you this
 and you keep your picture:
 you keep your pretty smile
 and all I’ve given you
 you
 get to keep;
 I don’t tell you
 and I’m left with that
 machine
 which I’ll leave
 when I finally sail away.

He’s left his swamp
 and his bank in the road
 behind him, are his passerby
 before him, now
 are the sleepless.

He waits
 and they reach out
 and he gives a finger
 and then a hand
 and then his head.

And he returns
 to his tower
 bricks and shingles
 leaving open his blinds
 and his door.

He's gone on too long
 Too proficient are his lies
 Too convincing
 is his face
 No one ever says hello.
pdfs/Ae'elles.pdf

You look me in that way
 and whisper to your friends
 behind closed hands
 just enough
 of your mouth
 so I may know.

We all want someone
 not always the same
 sometimes, it’s so
 I know enough
 and feel enough
 to know you feel for me.

But, does it flow?
 how may I know –
 with what’s barely come
 and besides, all this
 is not new;
 I’m recently versed.

I’m versed in that.
 not this.
 you are new; and i
 am not what I was
 I’m versed in those things
 You, are new.

Old roads have alleys
 with basements and attics
 glowing red
 and whispering spells
 whom am I
 to say I’ve seen your sound?

I think then, of you
 and find little:
 no room to deliberate
 no problem to solve
 and no mysteries to ponder
 Perhaps, I’m blind.

Moreso, I find
 I’ve walked well this road
 and, this time,
 You’ve the leash
 gently, leading me back
 as I hold it in one
 while twitching the other.

Something is near
 keeping me from my feet;
 from those cobbled streets,
 my darkened woods
 and bright groves.

That thing on the stairs
 crouching child, nearly young
 skin charred black
 head between its knees
 eyes down
 clothes so ragged
 they look like skin
 for so small a slip
 I see it sit
 there, on those steps,
 so help me
 I see you again, tomorrow
 I’ll know nothing more.

That thing on the stairs
 I see you again
 is it you?
 or is it me?
 maybe there’s no difference
 none anymore
 anyway.

It's near
 just away;
 in this way
 so seldom quick enough
 to see you there, sitting
 on your stairs
 you look at me
 with your head down
 funny, though
 I don’t even
 want you to leave
 don’t think I really care.

You come into my room
 you’ve done it before
 before the ocean
 now, here too
 I cannot escape
 the first time, I didn’t mind
 I welcomed your company
 you’re back again;
 rather, I’ve found you
 again
 well
 hello.

You’re a funny little thing
 I’m a funny little thing
 so help me if I see you
 tomorrow.

There’s this thing following me
 just out of sight
 I feel it, now,
 through closed blinds
 and my propped door
 which closes with a glance
 you pretend to hide
 you do this on purpose
 I do this on purpose, too
 it’s our game.

Where there was pity
 confused to be sympathy
 is now contempt
 manifested and realized
 from this burning core;
 that pool you swim from
 is shallow
 this gaze, drawn long
 is sharp
 accommodations are given
 like apologies
 between an older brother
 and a sobbing girl,
 smiles are produced
 not within
 but for without,
 you may hold my hand
 but I
 not yours.

There is much pain here
 You are my anti-Christ
 So far away
 I will never have you
 Only in death, may I come close
 besides,
 in death
 you’d kill me anyway.

You gloat to me
 Wide-eyed, open-mouthed
 waving arms and walking legs
 about how much
 you love to fuck.
 With who?
 Not with me.
 On this mission
 I’m missing you
 Oh, how I know
 When I see you next
 I’ll want to fold
 Either into you
 or by myself –
 By myself
 because you’re too busy
 doing what you love.

The last breath
 Stopping the snap
 it, only seconds,
 before it severs
 Draw this breath
 you command
 or else, disappointment;
 Draw this breath
 you say
 or else, manipulation;
 Force this breath
 you command
 or else, more of the same:
 We draw this breath
 and we are done –
 there’ll be nothing more
 to look forward to
 Heh
 We drew this breath
 now look!
 look where we are.
 You’re scarcely yourself;
 Without seeing you
 these past three years
 and I still, can tell
 that which you always refused.
 And me, I can’t stop
 all I am is myself
 and I find something new
 and can’t help being reminded
 of you;
 I can’t help remembering
 how much I had
 how much lingers
 and how little
 you still are;
 how little you were
 anyway.

I lay in my coma
 Within this temporary cell
 My externals burn
 heat’s filled my face
 itchiness taps my lungs
 rot’s consuming my signatures
 torn down, my defense is

 against myself,
 anyway, no longer
 self-respect, is there?
 If it’s there
 it's not my own.

Others sit, and I stand
 not awake, yet
 and I care not to
 Every feeling’s falsified
 every expression a joke
 every laugh’s forced
 and the smiles expected

Unto you
 when you finally dock
 here, eyes closed
 my heat will pass
 And I will open.

I’ve made it past the shallow
 These waves, no smaller
 Aren’t any bigger
 And there, before me:
 Those great big seas
 With all their oceans
 All filled to the top

I dip under
 the hair on my head, wet
 And I see reefs
 great beds of coral
 filled with fishes and eels
 little shells and brittle stars
 and colors painted pretty

A little further, now
 I paddle and swim
 There, before me:
 A great school of manta rays
 The giant jellyfish
 One whole leviathan
 It, to those deep depths

I’m yanked back.
 You, holding the other end
 This cable, wrapped around
 and caught my stomach.
 You are my last tether
 and my final reminder
 of my life on the land.

Laying under our passion tree
 Passing the purple fruits
 We, stumbling over,
 Have happened upon.

It streams from your lips
 Smelling like sweet-sense
 and tasting like wine
 My eyes fall sleepy

All these tall flowers
 And there, a horse by the creek
 you lean and kiss
 And me, the same.

The truth I seek:
 found in gurus and mystics,
 carved into cracks at the backs of caves
 and cast starry across a mountain’s night;
 hidden somewhere, formless,
 deep within some dark seething beast
 and still, then, only a clue
 a mere suggestion of what may be.

Those things you find
 printed pretty on colored paper
 and coded carefully
 so simply stumbled over
 and yet, heralded as prophets
 returning, finally, and fortunately,
 to luminate this otherwise
 unknown and unfathomable void.

Look down and find the feet
 and there still, on the floor
 Open your mouth
 and feel the moisture cool
 Take a little tumble
 and feel some bones break
 Open your eyes, just some,
 and see past what’s shown.

So hesitant to send
 away our seventh son
 the prodigal Adam, son of God
 the imagination’s machination.

 There goes Aryus
 Scaling the towers of stone
 and honing his grovel
 with flesh and hands.

And there, enters Armen
 And they walk and fish
 Hail traffic and take the train
 and suddenly, Soolaimon.

So suddenly, one starry night
 Comets carrying the sky
 and in its still
 there between, Soolaimon.

So scared to send
 and so forth our seventh son
 the prodigal Adam, son of God,
 for fear he will return.

Disillusioned so long
 trampled, beaten, and berated
 belittled and disrespected
 ripped, severed, and shamed
 opened, peeled, and filled
 to be thrown away again.

Over and over
 for years and years
 Spitting so I may swallow
 Circling so I may fall
 To these and them, couch and bed
 never me, and never us

A strange sunset
 that I surely have found
 Something so surreal
 To flee, is my instinct,
 to refuse, to abandon
 to jump away and drown.

But welcome… this new sun
 against the cold so set, so warm
 so good, so tender, and so sweet;
 melt this demeanor stoned
 and let the heart I once owned
 be once more mine.

Precautions, now, disregarded
 Not necessarily ever needed
 But now, suddenly, such is obvious
 They creep up and are buried
 These precautions, now, surely,
 need not be heeded.

Meddled mind but clear wants
 With no less restraint or control;
 With no less vision and honor
 rather, something new,
 A complete and utter regard
 For what may be manifested

Given I just go.

Eyes wide-tired
 Friends from home
 and home is not here
 Home is long ago
 and there is nothing here
 From all that before.

Something fixes everything
 Is there and ready
 Pluck it, simply
 Pick it and eat it
 From you, it’s already grown
 Into you, it has long been bound.

Your issue is mine
 Your concern is otherworldly
 of demons and faeries
 When all the fantasy
 and all your fruit
 are waiting to be had.

Believe our words
 His, if not mine,
 and theirs’, if not these
 A friend is like family
 One friend, a brother
 A friend, is a friend

Your consideration
 Merely one of my many
 So thoughtful, so fruitful
 How kind, and how caring.

I claim nothing
 And you plant your stake
 into my open chest
 Ignorant to your arrogance.

 You cannot fathom
 These thoughts, of mine,
 This little counter you claim
 Is barely a whisper.

You appear as a friend
 And consider yourself such
 And I, the same
 I believe you.

My judgment burns
 Opinions and beliefs, a doctrine
 Of which is my own
 And have kept it such.

And, truly, you are clueless
 I refrain whilst you proclaim
 So many times, so many years
 and you abandon me.

You dare say you’re jealous
 Try living your own life
 You dare whistle suicide
 You can try living mine.

 Maybe I should be temperate…
 God forbid I’m angry
 And God forbid, I feel good
 Just once.

I think I remember reading somewhere
 When you’re down and tired
 You return to things since shed
 So long ago
 or yesterday

Exhaustion
 Skin is hot
 Brain is running
 poking, flowing, melting
 I can’t see
 I can’t think
 I’m down
 and I’m low

Counting the minutes
 Hoping they would pass
 So I may waste the rest
 and continue to itch

Scratch and pick
 Tear and bleed;
 If only I would bleed
 Out, in little pools
 From my filthy pores
 Acid coagulated
 Stiff and full
 Stuck and filling

I’m realizing myself

You’ll find my flag
And I’ll wear yours

Under red lips and shy eyes
We’ll finally come to find.

I don’t even care

We’re back again 
This time, the final time
I’ve topped summits in the sun
Come twilight, I’ve toppled
Great monuments of stone
And, some nights, 
I happen upon sleep
And from others
I wake unchanged. 

Five milligrams of heroin
I feel absolutely nothing
The dog days remain
Sometimes, I feel something
An inkling of a feeling
A sarcastic suggestion
Of that meticulously constructed. 
There’s a happy song about suicide
And to it, I laugh. 

I do not belong
My allegiances are made up
My connections contrived
My desires deliberated
Decided, second-hand
The weather’s an excuse
The law, a ruse
And the suffering
I wake unchanged. 

I am no slave
And I am no king
I am no demon
And I am no hero
I cannot nail
And I sleep on hardwood
I cannot walk
And I run in circles
And at them, I laugh. 

I do not want anything anymore. 
Maybe I’d want someone to stay
And I don’t want people to go
But I’ll throw them out
And I’ll throw them away.
My being is broken
My lust, twisted and torn
My love, raped and burned
Killed, buried, and covered. 

I’m coming back again
To a land forsaken
Last time, I cried
And now I don’t bother
I deserve nothing
And I owe everything
I know nothing
And I know everything
I wake unchanged. 

I remember I use to miss you
One I knew I hated
And one I knew I wanted
One easy, youthful wish
With red-faced smiles
And a hand brushing hair
The other, a perversion
A mockery, and my own diversion
And at it, I’m trying to laugh. 

I am back again
Back for a season’s worth more
And there’ll be a time sometime
Suddenly, unconsciously, 
I will be able to laugh. 
And for all my blood
And for every bitter tear
I will find a smile.
I am not unchanged.

These streets are all marked
And to this wilderness
From the lowlands to the peaks
The trails are mastered
The caves and holds, discovered
And where there was room
A new trail was charted. 

There may remain a tree unclimbed
And a path unwalked
Before, when I came here
There were many
And the sun, for hours, 
Would hang lightly and low
But now, such things are few. 

Even then, that unlikely reveal
In that discrete until found
I’ve happened upon the Holy Grail
A gift greater than any other
Externally, it’s tangible, it’s real
A way to lay my weary head
And inside - a way to rest my eyes.

In those old world woods
And up those cliffs once climbed
There are clearings
There are lakes
There are the moon and stars
And there are visions of fireballs:
Those places that bonfires burn. 

But beyond these places
There are the great northern lands
Of canyons, pines, and white winters
There’s that fateful place
The skyless sea meets the sun
Then past, those lands unseen
Resting in an old radio. 

And in that imagination
There are arrangements arranged
Rhymes, rehearsed and recited;
There are plans well laid
In the language well learned. 
And of these limitations, I implore
To release me. 

But that beautiful omen
A star, blazing across the sky
Ripping and tugging me through time
In its grace, I understand
There is time to be tempered
There is gravity to be governed
And I am free.

This cursed month of March

This cursed month of March

This cursed month of March
I cannot deny

This cursed month of March
I cannot deny

This cursed month of March
I cannot deny

This cursed month of March

All those months of March

This month of March
I will not hide
I remember our New Year’s day.

After all, feeling creeps through cowering fingers 
After all, feelings creep through to covered faces.

Do I even remember

A blip back in time

Or is it desperate nostalgia

Do you even remember

Do I even remember

I am the man out of time.
On that rocky precipice
Dawnbreaker’s dusk ahead of me
Neither high or low
Everything, neither near or far
From my body, I emerged
And I took to the wing.

For hours, I scoured the skies
But before long, I flew to the island
There, I collected my lover
Nervous at first, he let fall his head
It coming to rest, next to mine.
Lifting him, I wrapped us in silver
And we set sail under the sun. 

Together, we traveled all the land
Broke bread in cobblestone hollows
And drank wine in sand-burnt castles -
And if ever there was fire, we flew elsewhere;
We swam in the sea of the porcelain beach
We laid in fields of cherries and reeds
And that precious within us - we shared. 

Bombs and guns on the horizon
I looked to him, and I could see the lines
We went together, smoke behind the shadow
A rising sun, always upon the dawn.
I woke, and I looked, and his eyes were weary
I carried him between the cliffs
Tears in mine, I spent those days with him. 

When I left those highlands
Walking, my coat with the wind
I stood upon that abandoned beach:
I looked to the sun above the sea
Far from the horizon, but not nearly in the sky;
I felt, far away, brimstone and bombshells
And I delved deep into knowledge.

I was the man without time
Coughing within decrepit catacombs
And blowing dust off skin-leather books.
Deep underground, I dug, peering ahead
A single candle lighting my way;
Then, through and above the flakfire
I climbed to the top of those old towers.

From those brick balconies
With the smell of untouched tea
I looked upon that ravaged land
The sea, covered by a dark reaching fog
Then, into my own, I inhaled the fumes.
With a plume of dust, I slammed my book shut
And from my pocket, I drew a chunk of chalk. 

First, across the sidewalks; and then, in classrooms
I constructed my figures, running the calculations
Eyes dry, sweat down my brow
And my wings burning ablaze
I proved and postulated, until people began to point
I was invited, heralded, and celebrated
A scepter from the smoke.

And I cut through it all
Delegated with absolute degree
Discriminated by undeniable decree:
The conglomerates, the senates, the assemblies
Just the same with the seats, the thrones, and the drones
A terrible retribution - I cut through it all
And from my horizon, the smoke started to recede. 

I championed over every challenge
Proving wrong every falsehood, every lie
And perforated the sole precious truth.
Then, amongst the red trumpets and applause
Globe in one hand, goblet in the other
All these people, and an empty seat beside me
I stared and I lost the sound.

I was without time. 
Every drink devisable, and every sip conceivable;
Every odorous rise, and every sweet-smelling fall;
Anything a man may eat
And then, anything a man may feel
And then, anything a man may be
I consumed it all.

Memory was a pained reminder
Then, I needed reminding of the memory.
After that, I wished for that small sensation
How a single tear would trickle, at some sad song.
Wood, stones, fire, and bones
Bones, fire, stones, and wood
All the same, and the same was all.

Music filling my ears
A song, then a song not at all.
In a wished-for fever, I commissioned a vessel
I stepped foot on that abandoned beach
Then, like the very day
I made for that spot between those cliffs
And there, I sat and cried. 

Music filling my ears
A song, then a song not at all.
From a memory I was feeling, I set sail
And I stumbled upon that abandoned beach
I wandered lost, until I was suddenly aware
I stared, seeing through the fog surrounding me
At some vision that was not there. 

Sound reaching my ears
A song, then not.
I woke up on that abandoned beach
I was amongst limestone homes
I was mooring a raft, stepping onto that beach
I was sitting, between the cliffs, at a spot in the land
I turn to leave. Then I am there again. 

My eyes open, and I am somewhere else
Every organism, every single microcosm
Perceived and dissected with disturbing perfection
Until the revulsions, the satisfactions, the perversions
All that too, fading into the dawnbreaker’s dusk.
There, again, a vision - a single silhouette. 
An old man, he waits for me. 

I follow him, taking to the wing
Seeing him now, his beard is full, and his hair is long
But his face bears no lines
And his wings are as swift as mine.
I open my mouth to speak
And I hear the words he says to me -
I heard the words he said to me. 

“I want to show you,” he said,
“Did you think you were the only one?”
And as we sail down to a newborn isle
Passing like wisps, but material nonetheless
There are people, and only a few look our way
Nowhere has age graced them
Despite the life departed from their eyes. 

I remember then, in an eternity’s instant
My own tears, how they flowed
When I held my lover in the highlands;
“I want to say, that I am sorry,” the man said to me,
“Although those things, you cannot feel
They cannot, and I cannot either
I could argue that that sorrow is sensible
Maybe at one time, there may have been some sentiment
All this, everything; if you have not already
You will come to know.
This, you well understand;
I could admit, if it were as such
That this was my desperation.”

My mouth makes no words
My companion is beside me, and I do not see him
Everywhere and nowhere; everything and nothing.
I remember all that ever happened.
I know all that’s happening.
I recall all that I felt, and the flame’s faded.
I am out of time.

Okay, here it goes
I am adrift down the sea
Ship’s gone, I am my vessel
Alone, I’ve gone numb
Gonna throw up my lifeline. 

Remember, everything in order
I saw her, just ahead;
I called to her, she turned her head
Side by side, we walked
Happy as friends would be.

Watching movies my comrades could not believe
Settling into circumstances
That my confidante, for, would have dreamed
Smiling, he patted my back, leading me home
All while I could not look him in the eye;
As directed, as prescribed, all those details
Perfectly organized, as per a miracle
And yet, all I could do was eat -
Finally together, all I could do was sleep.
Over you, I studied your eyelids
How your lips would be just apart
The way your breath met the air
And listened, and listened, for you to whisper;
Then, when you opened your eyes,
You would never see
But I rushed to close mine. 

Infested, rot filling my gut
Following mine, finding freedom, I pulled the plug
And I think of your pain, now
And I wonder, instead, if I had laid my head
But I remember now, the world opened
I think of this only as I try to close it;
I feel this only when I am falling. 

I would have wanted to have stayed your friend
To not be afraid to call your name, and to walk as we did.
I told you once, I see myself out if I serve no purpose
Exile myself, if there’s no explicit justification
But friendship is explicit enough. 

There was one before
She is the one that lurks in the swamp
Emerging, rising, at the pit of the fall
All to sink away, into the dark;
I remember everything she ever did. 

And as I reached and clawed, I blamed her hatefully
I hung myself, hopelessly holding her memory
Attributing the death of you and I to that past. 
But for all that torture, that second-hand, the doubt and fear
Every sorrow - she was the icon with which I bled myself. 

Remember now, everything blown apart
Picking up my shaking pieces, I picked you out
Measuring, postulating, theorizing - I charted a course;
In my head exactly, I wrote that plot, I drew up that storyboard;
I envisioned a great insurrection - and then, a holy vindication. 

As written before, you were no saint, and I am no satan
I was a Lucifer - proud beyond prideful, and ambitious beyond arrogance.
I had the means too, but thank God I failed
With you, Beatrice, I would have fallen far beyond Hell.
I am wiser, now, but, back then, I was by no means a fool.

Unto you, fiery retribution will fall
But not by my hand, for I refuse to be that man
However it may be, I hope you find it on your own.
Innocent though, just and pure, was that I destroyed;
May I be strong enough, so I may, one day, help in some way
And, when I leave, may you never know. 

May I stand trial.
May I be stood, nailed, and may I burn for my crimes,
While I live witness for each of my sins.
Your love, and your care - you are in my heart
Your words - I will keep them in my head.
All that time, that nearly tenured, with each of you, 
What exactly have I lost?
With all of you, all you people, and every slept-walked hollow
Where did I stumble, how did I feel, and what have I found?
Farewell my sums and pieces - I’ll not be around
This tired melodrama, along with the last, are coming to a close
I remember what I lost, and I know what I have found.
I will arrange every precious piece, every dear desire
Hold them with honor, and support them with steel
If you want me, then follow my lifeline
That passed is yours. 
These words, these acts, they are mine.
